Let $f$ be a function from all pairs of elements in $\{1,\ldots,n\}$ to $\{1,\ldots,n\}$ such that $f(x,y)\neq x$ and $\neq y$ for all $x,y$. We call $X\subseteq \{1,\ldots,n\}$ independent if whenever $x,y\in X$ we have $f(x,y)\not\in X$.

Let $g(n)$ be such that, in every function $f$, there is an independent set of size at least $g(n)$. Estimate $g(n)$.



A question of Erd\H{o}s and Hajnal \cite{ErHa58}, who could prove\[n^{1/3} \ll g(n) \ll (n\log n)^{1/2}.\]Spencer \cite{Sp72} proved $g(n)\gg n^{1/2}$. Conlon, Fox, and Sudakov \cite{CFS16} proved $g(n)\ll n^{1/2}$.




References


[CFS16] Conlon, David and Fox, Jacob and Sudakov, Benny, Short proofs of some extremal results {II}. J. Combin. Theory Ser. B (2016), 173--196.

[ErHa58] Erd\H{o}s, P. and Hajnal, A., On the structure of set mappings. Acta Math. Acad. Sci. Hungar. (1958), 111-133.

[Sp72] Spencer, Joel, Tur\'an's theorem for {$k$}-graphs. Discrete Math. (1972), 183--186.
